About This Game

What would you do if you had the keys to the zoo?
World of Zoo is the only life sim game that pushes you past the fences and into a world of your own zoo.
Create and customize your zoo experience and develop hands on relationships to earn the trust and love of your animals.
  • Build on relationships with the world’s most amazing animals through hands on interaction
  • Create unlimited animals with the Animal Creator
  • Hours of play with mini-games, achievements and unlockables
  • Create and customize your own zoo
  • Experience over 40 different animal species
  • Learn about each animal with the National Geographic animal fact cards
  • Connect online and share user generated content
* Some of the animals depicted in the trailer and screenshots are not included in the current version.
READ MORE

System Requirements

    • OS: Microsoft Windows XP/Vista
    • Processor: Intel Pentium IV processor running at 2 GHz, AMD 64, Core 2 duo 1.6Ghz or equivalent
    • Memory: 512 MB RAM (1 GB RAM on Vista)
    • Graphics: Nvidia GeForce 6600 GT or ATI Radeon x1600 with at least 64MB of memory (video cards with Pixel Shader version 1.1 or better are required)
    • Display: DirectX-compatible display capable of 800x600 resolution in 16-bit color
    • DirectX®: DirectX 9.0c and above
    • Hard Drive: 2GB of hard drive space
    • Sound: Sound: 16-bit Sound Blaster Compatible

Was this review helpful? Yes No Funny
4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
2 people found this review funny
Mathew Mii
47 products in account
1 review
Not Recommended
4.0 hrs on record
Posted: May 25
When I decide on games to buy for the Wii, I had one rule that prevent bowing money on bad games: Never buy a game from a third company except Okami. World of Zoo is a good reason for the rule, even though I payed for this game dirt cheap on Steam instead of buying it for my Wii. I do praise the game for being gentle on PC parts, temperature wise; I also praise it for including animal customization, believable animal sounds, a fun art style, and the attempt to be educational. However, the game play is very poor from the controls, mechanics, and a lack of challenge.

I will start with the controls. I understand that this game is on the Nintendo Wii and the controls were meant for the Wii-Mote pointing at the screen. The transition from Wii-Mote to mouse and keyboard went well, but I am very concerned about the left-handed people who want to play this. Unless they go through the control panel, there is no way to play this on left handed mode. In game, the clicking commands do not work 100% of the time.

There is another in game issue and those are the mechanics, or how the game works. The first thing that irks me is the fact that you are a camera stick in one position with the only movement being pivoting from the spot. This causes some of the clicking command issues I have mentioned earlier. For example, there was a treasure that was behind a play set structure. Most of the clicks landed on the structure instead of the treasure spot. If I had the ability to move my camera around more freely, stuff like that could have been prevented. The animals also have response issues, especially since there is no ability to pick a specific one for separate commanding. The last complaint in this department is the use of an annoying video game trope. I don't know what it is called, but here's how it functions: You keep playing the game to unlock a needed thing, but it is useless because there is no more game play value (Pokemon Mystery Dungeon Explorers of Time/Darkness is guilty for this, but I can't explain why because it will contain spoilers). Going back to World of Zoo, the game made me play one enclosure for a long time with 2 animals just to unlock certain parts to create my ideal 3rd creature. This is indeed optional, but nobody should have to deal with the struggle of staying awake in boredom for a creature that will barely be played with once the player leaves the exhibit.

Speaking of struggling with wakefulness, the game lacks a good challenge. Having a "needs" bars like hunger and sleepiness would be a good fix to this issue. The challenges the game provides are too easy and they are not leveled according to animal count. I know that this game is meant for kids, but that does not excuse it from this issue. The Super Mario series are for kids, but they provide fair challenges that even stump some adults.

Overall, this is not a good game to buy because of controls, mechanics, and a lack of challenge. If you are a parent looking for educational material covering animals for your kids, I would pass this game and have them watch Zaboomafoo instead.
Read More

unusualPopsicle
161 products in account
5 reviews
Not Recommended
8.9 hrs on record
Posted: January 4
Fun game if you want to just goof around with adorable critters. bought the game with full excitement of "OH MAN CUTE THINGS" and was only disappointed to find that there are only these families to pick from for animals in the PC version:

- Big Cats
- Horses
- Giraffes
- Small Monkeys
- Koalas
- Pandas

The disappointment sets in when you realize, the game for Wii, has the above plus the following:

- Bears
- Penguins
- Crocodiles
- Antelopes
- Elephants

I looked it up, maybe there was a code or something for getting the other families, nope! Turns out the World of Zoo group was apparently laid off by Blue Fang, leaving half of the PC version incomplete. SOOOOO DON'T EXPECT TO GET THE REST OF THOSE ANIMALS ON PC ANY TIME SOON.

Other than that, if you've got no beef with the above I'd say buy it, it's really fun , I'm just a little peeved I don't get the game I was expecting. Know what you're getting into.

Yes I'm mostly upset I can't have a virtual Croc buddy. I was excited due to the fact that I haven't got a Wii and I've wanted this game for a while now.

A little let down, but it is a game meant for children, not 22 year olds with no life and tons of time on their hands. Feeling a little ripped off, glad I didn't buy it at full price, thanks Blue Fang. At least make some DLC for the rest of the animals or somethin?

Posted: February 21, 2014
It would be nice if the developers owned and embraced the fact the game is definetly oriented towards younger kids. I found out about it online while looking for a game for my kids so I bought it knowing full well what I was buying. I can see how some people may have bought the game thinking it was something more than what it is. Either way my 5 year old loves it and its something we get to do together so great game in that regard. Not recomended for gamers though.
